metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Respondent (Jhajjar Constituency Election Petition)

facts.text: Election to Haryana Vidhan Sabha from Jhajjar constituency held on 11-3-1972 in which appellant declared elected with 24060 votes against respondent's 23975 votes.
Respondent filed Election Petition No. 45 of 1972 challenging validity of election.
Punjab and Haryana High Court Single Judge by order dated 17-8-1972 allowed issues 1,2,3,4,5,6,7a,7b in election petition.

Allegations in para 9(ii): 28 votes of dead voters polled at specified booths: Chhapa Booth 19, Machhrauli 31, Silani 38,39, Silani Pans Zalim 40, Silani Panna Keso 41, Bhadani 56, Chhudani 58, Sheikhupura Jat 61, Badli 79. Schedule I lists 28 names with death dates (except 4) and 24 death certificates produced.
710 voters absent, missing, sick in hospitals, convicts in jail, deserted ladies impersonated by friends/relations of respondent.
158 Government servants not present in villages, did not cast votes, but impersonated for respondent. Schedule IV lists names, employment details.

Votes of same persons registered/polled in two or more places in Jhajjar (44) and other constituencies (Beri 42, Salhawas SC 43, Bahadurgarh 45, Kalanaur 41, Hasangarh 38, Pataudi 55, Jatusana 58) and Delhi villages (Ghewra, Mitrau, Dichau, Charagh Delhi). Chemicals used to evaporate indelible ink for multiple voting. Example: Sister Mano impersonated Mitro (934), Shanti (940) at Booth 40, and voted herself at 40(824) and Booth 1(41). About 149 persons voted twice/multiple times (Schedule V).
Appellant denied allegations and filed recrimination petition alleging similar irregularities against himself for 2200 votes.
Schedule III: 705 names with polling stations/booths, electoral roll numbers, fathers/husbands names; 44 cases name impersonators; reasons for absence.
Schedule V: Includes appellant, wife, brother, daughters, son, driver, driver's wife voting twice; details 149 double/multiple votes.

Issue 6 corrupt practice: Respondent visited Bhatera village week before Holi ~20-2-1972, with Thakur Mohinder Singh requested votes via Fakirda, Sukhdev s/o Mania, Maru Singh s/o Gulzari. Harijans (Bhiku s/o Muni Lal etc.) and backward classes declined. Threatened by Mohinder Singh (Rajput) with social/economic boycott or not vote. Agents Bhanwar Singh, Pandit Rattan Lal visited 23-2-1972 to 10-3-1972 threatening life/property. No votes cast out of 568 at Booth 28. Petitioner informed DSP Ved Parkash night 10-11 March; DSP enquired, confirmed fear; no safeguards/re-poll under s.57 RPA.

Counting started 12-3-1972 at 6.30 pm, 12 tables, till 2.50 am 13-3-1972. Objections by petitioner's agents on tables 2,3,4,5,10,12 for improper bundling. Petitioner leading by 239 after third round. Fourth round: bundles >50 for petitioner declared 50, <50 for respondent. Table 6 recount: 76 petitioner papers in respondent bundles. >300 petitioner votes wrongly counted for respondent on those tables. ~100 valid petitioner votes rejected, ~100 invalid respondent declared valid. ~500 petitioner votes to respondent. Applications for recount at 00.50 hrs and 2.30 am 13-3-1972 rejected. No test check by RO. No copy of second application given.
1100 witnesses cited, Rs.60,000 deposited for summoning.

legal_issues.text: Whether election petition contains concise statement of material facts (issues 1,3,4,5 re impersonation, dead/absent voters, double voting) under s.83(1)(a) RPA or lacks particulars requiring evidence, amounting to roving/fishing inquiry.
Whether particulars of corrupt practice (issue 6: undue influence in Bhatera) sufficient under s.83(1)(b) RPA.
Whether allegations of counting irregularities (issues 7a,7b) raise triable issues.

petitioner_arguments.text: Election petition lacks material particulars for issues 1,3,4,5; seeks roving/fishing inquiry; must specify who impersonated dead/absent; challenges only possible if polling agents challenged under Rule 36 CER 1961; 1100 witnesses alarming.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 83(1)(a),(b) RPA 1951; Rule 36 Conduct of Election Rules 1961

petitioner_arguments.text: Issues should not be allowed as petition requires evidence, not just facts.

respondent_arguments.text: Petition gives elaborate details in paras 9(ii),(iv),(v),(vi) and Schedules I,III,IV,V; more than required; no blanket ballot inspection, only after proving impersonation via voters/counterfoils.
Full particulars for corrupt practice in paras 13,14: names, dates, places, no votes out of 568.
Detailed allegations of counting irregularities in paras 27-31 raise triable issues.

court_reasoning.text: Petition gives minute details beyond requirement; Schedules provide names, dates, reasons, certificates; distinguishes material facts from evidence per O.VI R.2 CPC; no need to name impersonators if absence proven; polling agent challenges not mandatory as agents may be absent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Election petition amply states material facts; rarely such elaborate details.

court_reasoning.text: Issue 6: Paras 13,14 give names, dates, places of undue influence; no votes cast significant; triable.
Issues 7a,7b: Specific paras 27-31 on bundling, rejections, recount refusals; at pleadings stage, triable; corrupt practices quasi-criminal but allegations not vague.
Trial judge to manage evidence efficiently, e.g. affidavits first, reduce oral exams; no hard rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Exacting work but cannot shirk; 1100 witnesses possible.

holdings.text: Election petition contains sufficient material facts and particulars; issues 1-7b rightly framed and triable; no roving inquiry.
Particulars of corrupt practice under s.83(1)(b) satisfied.
Counting irregularity allegations raise triable issues.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Requirements for election petition particulars; corrupt practices quasi-criminal; adjournment of poll.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Pleadings contain material facts only, not evidence.

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court order allowing trial on issues 1-7b dismissed; no substance in contentions; parties to cooperate for efficient trial.

key_quotes.text: "One would have to search long and wide in order to come across any election Petition Which gives such elaborate details."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms sufficiency of particulars in petition.

key_quotes.text: "Every pleading shall contain, and contain only, a statement in a concise form of the material facts... but not the evidence by which they are to be proved."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites O.VI R.2 CPC to reject demand for evidence in pleadings.

key_quotes.text: "Charges of corrupt practices under s.123... are quasi-criminal in nature, and should, therefore, be proved satisfactorily."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Notes standard of proof for trial stage.
